title: R43557
content: The report provides an overview of FY2015 legislative branch appropriations, detailing actions such as the submission of requests, hearings, markups, and the passage of relevant bills. It also includes information on prior year actions and funding, budget requests, hearings, and funding issues for individual legislative branch agencies. Tables list funding levels for FY2014 and FY2015 budget requests. The FY2015 U.S. Budget requested $4.471 billion for legislative branch activities, with hearings held in 2014. The House subcommittee marked up the FY2015 bill on April 4, 2014, providing $3.3 billion. The full House Appropriations Committee then considered one amendment before ordering the bill reported. On April 9, 2014, the full House Appropriations Committee held a markup of the FY2015 bill. Representative Moran proposed a housing stipend for Members living 50 miles away from DC, which failed. The House considered H.R. 4487 on May 1, 2014, with amendments including funding restrictions on vehicle leasing and sexual harassment training. The House Appropriations Committee approved various amendments to the FY2015 bill, including reducing funding for the Botanic Garden and Capitol Visitor Center, defunding the Open World Leadership Center Trust Fund, and prohibiting the delivery of printed materials to Members of the House. Additionally, an amendment to reinstitute the Office of Technology Assessment with offset funds was proposed. The House Appropriations Committee approved amendments to the FY2015 bill, including reducing funding for various areas and prohibiting printed materials delivery. A failed amendment by Representative Holt sought to appropriate $2.5 million to reinstitute the Office of Technology Assessment. H.R. 4487, as amended, passed the House by a vote of 402-14. The Senate Appropriations Committee considered the bill but no further action was taken before the start of FY2015. Funding for the legislative branch was provided through continuing resolutions until the Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act, 2015 was enacted on December 16, 2014. In FY2014, a funding gap led to a partial government shutdown for 16 days until a CR (P.L. 113-46) was enacted on October 17, 2013. This CR provided funding until January 15, 2014, when a consolidated appropriations bill (P.L. 113-76) allocated $4.259 billion for the legislative branch. Prior to this, FY2013 funding of $4.061 billion was provided by P.L. 113-6 on March 26, 2013, with exceptions and rescissions to meet spending limits. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act, as amended by the Budget Control Act of 2011 and the American Taxpayer Relief Act of 2012, set discretionary spending limits. OMB calculated additional rescissions for security and nonsecurity budget authority after P.L. 113-6. Sequestration reductions implemented on March 1 reduced legislative branch accounts by 5.0%. Division G of the FY2012 Consolidated Appropriations Act provided $4.307 billion for the legislative branch, $236.9 million below the FY2011 level. In FY2009, the legislative branch budget received $4.402 billion from the FY2009 Omnibus Appropriations Act. Additional funding was provided for the Government Accountability Office and Capitol Police radio system. The Senate requested $907.2 million for FY2015, with the final act providing $864.3 million, a 0.6% increase from FY2014. The Senate requested $134.0 million for inquiries and investigations, with the FY2015 act providing $133.3 million. The Committee on Appropriations received $14.94 million, and the Senators' Official Personnel and Office Expense Account was allocated $429.7 million for FY2015. The Senate Appropriations Committee recommended $390.0 million for the SOPOEA, the same level as FY2014. The Senate requested $429.7 million for FY2015, with the Senate Appropriations Committee recommending and the FY2015 act providing $390.0 million, the same level as FY2014. The House requested $1.20 billion for FY2015, but the House-passed level of $1.18 billion remained the same as FY2014. Funding for House committees is detailed in the appropriation heading "committee employees," with the House requesting $126.3 million and the FY2015 act providing $123.9 million. The Committee on Appropriations funding remained at $23.3 million, the same as FY2014. The House requested $23.7 million for the Committee on Appropriations, while $565.4 million was requested for the Members' Representational Allowance. The U.S. Capitol Police requested $355.7 million for FY2015, with the House-passed bill providing $348.0 million. The police appropriations are divided into salaries and general expenses accounts. The USCP budget is presented in Table 7, with appropriations divided into salaries and general expenses accounts. The salaries account covers employee salaries, benefits, and contributions, while the general expenses account includes expenses for equipment, training, and other administrative support. The Capitol Police requested $291.4 million for salaries, an increase of 4.4% from FY2014, and $64.3 million for general expenses. The House-passed bill provided $286.5 million for salaries and the FY2015 act funded at the same level. The Capitol Police requested $64.3 million for general expenses, an 8.1% increase from FY2014. The House-passed bill would have provided $61.5 million (+3.4%), while the Senate recommended $499 increase. USCP also requested $25.6 million for Capitol Police buildings and grounds, a 32.3% increase from FY2014. The House-passed bill would have provided $19.5 million (+0.7%), and the Senate recommended $20.7 million (+6.8%). The Senate subcommittee discussed USCP involvement, discrimination complaints, and door closures in the House side of the Capitol. The Office of Compliance requested $4.02 million for FY2015, with the House Appropriations Committee recommending $3.96 million. The House-passed bill included $4.5 million, with funds for sexual harassment training. The Senate-reported bill proposed $3.96 million. The Senate-reported bill for FY2015 provided $3.96 million for training for House offices, with funds offset from the general administration fund of the Architect of the Capitol. The bill also included language authorizing the Office of Compliance to send notifications to covered employees electronically. The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) requested $46.1 million for FY2015, with the House-passed bill providing $45.7 million and the Senate-reported bill providing $46.1 million. Discussions at hearings focused on CBO projections and recent findings in CBO products. The subcommittee discussed CBO projections and recent findings at a Senate hearing. CBO requested two administrative provisions for FY2015 funds. The Architect of the Capitol is responsible for maintaining the U.S. Capitol Complex. Operations of the Architect are funded separately. The Architect of the Capitol requested $676.6 million for FY2015, an increase of 12.4% from FY2014, including funding for the Capitol Dome restoration project. The House-passed bill provided $484.9 million, with amendments to reduce funding for the Botanic Garden and offset training costs. The Senate-reported bill proposed $600.0 million, while the FY2015 act allocated $600.2 million (-0.3%). The FY2015 act provided $600.2 million for the Architect of the Capitol, with provisions related to educational outreach efforts and prohibiting bonuses for contractors behind schedule or over budget. Discussions at House and Senate subcommittee hearings included funding for the Capitol Dome rehabilitation project and renovation plans for the Cannon House Office Building. The Library of Congress serves as Congress's library and the national library of the United States, with services including acquisition, maintenance, preservation of a collection of over 158 million items, administration of copyright laws, and providing reading material to the blind. It also offers legal research, policy analysis, and legislative assistance to Congress. The Library of Congress provides legislative assistance, staff training, information retrieval, and legal education for Members and staff. The FY2015 budget requested $593.1 million, with the final allocation being $590.9 million. Salaries and expenses saw an increase to $413.0 million, and the Copyright Office budget increased to $19.5 million. The FY2015 budget for the Library of Congress requested $593.1 million, with final allocation at $590.9 million. The Copyright Office requested $19.5 million, with the House-passed bill providing $20.7 million. The Congressional Research Service requested $108.4 million, with the FY2015 act providing $106.9 million. The Books for the Blind and Physically Handicapped requested $50.7 million, with the FY2015 act providing $50.2 million. The Architect's budget also includes funds for Library buildings and grounds. The Library of Congress FY2015 budget requested $593.1 million, with a final allocation of $590.9 million. The budget included funds for Library buildings and grounds, with a requested $62.8 million for FY2015. The House-passed bill allocated $41.7 million, the Senate-reported bill allocated $47.6 million, and the FY2015 act provided $42.2 million. GPO requested $128.9 million for FY2015, with the House-passed bill providing $122.6 million and the Senate-reported bill providing $122.1 million. The FY2015 budget for the Government Publishing Office (GPO) requested $128.9 million. The House-passed bill allocated $122.6 million, the Senate-reported bill allocated $122.1 million, and the FY2015 act provided $119.99 million. GPO's budget authority is divided into three accounts, with changes in names for each account. The requested amount for congressional publishing was $85.4 million, while the amount for Public Information Programs of the Superintendent of Documents (salaries and expenses) was $32.2 million. The Government Publishing Office Business Operations Revolving Fund remained at the FY2014 level. The FY2015 budget for the Government Publishing Office (GPO) requested $128.9 million. The House-passed, Senate-reported, and enacted bills contained $31.5 million for the Government Publishing Office Business Operations Revolving fund. The FY2015 act provided $8.8 million, with a provision redesignating the Government Printing Office as the Government Publishing Office. The House subcommittee discussed GPO's FY2015 budget request in April 2014. GAO requested $525.1 million for FY2015, with the enacted bill providing $522.0 million. GAO also requested three administrative provisions. The Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 authorized the detail of personnel to GAO and established a Center for Audit Excellence. H.R. 4487 included language for the Center, which was also included in the FY2015 act. House and Senate subcommittees discussed GAO's requests, savings from recommendations, and plans for the Center. The Open World Leadership Center supports democratic changes by inviting foreign leaders to observe democracy in the U.S., starting with a program for Russian leaders in 1999. The Open World Leadership Center was established in 2000 to support the relationship between Russia and the United States by inviting young Russian leaders to observe the U.S. government and society. It was renamed in 2003 and expanded to include more countries. The center requested $8.0 million for FY2015, with the House-passed bill proposing $3.42 million and the Senate-reported bill proposing $5.7 million. The Open World Leadership Center, established in 2000 to support US-Russia relations, requested $8.0 million for FY2015. The Senate-reported bill proposed $5.7 million, a decrease of $300,000 from FY2014. The center was created by Congress in 1988 to encourage public service by congressional staff through training programs. The requested funding for FY2015 was $430,000, the same as FY2014. The Committee did not receive the budget justification requested in H.Rept. 112-148, leading to zero funding provided for the John C. Stennis Center for Public Service Training and Development. The Center has $15 million invested with the Treasury, generating $300,000 annually. Further budget requests must be accompanied by a detailed budget justification. The Committee directs that future budget requests from the John C. Stennis Center must include a detailed budget justification. The Center received funding in previous fiscal years and there were provisions in H.R. 4487 and P.L. 113-235 regarding appropriations for maintenance, compensation rates, consulting services contracts, and pay freeze for Members of Congress in 2015. The FY2015 act included a provision freezing pay for Members of Congress in 2015. Salaries for Members of Congress are not funded or increased in any appropriations bill. Provisions to prohibit automatic adjustments have been discussed in other bills. The Senate-reported bill also included restrictions on bonus awards to contractors for projects behind schedule or over budget. P.L. 113-235 prohibits funds for painting portraits of officers or employees. The FY2015 act includes a provision prohibiting funds for painting portraits of federal government officers or employees. Tables provide funding information for the legislative branch, Senate, House of Representatives, Capitol Police, and Architect of the Capitol. Selected websites offer details on legislative branch appropriations requests and the appropriations process.
